results.occurrenceRemarks: An adult bat with the below morphometric measurements  Mass = 28g, Forearm =50mm, Tibia = 21.5mm, Tail = 34mm
Brown above, yellow underneath, dark wings.
This bat crawled out of the ceiling :-)
C-C: 7.4, M^3-M^3: 10.7  dorsal pelage olive, ventral pelage yellow
C-C: 7.0, M^3-M^3: 10.6, C-M^3: 7.55  dorsal pelage olive, ventral pelage yellow
C-C: 7.0, M^3-M^3: 10.6  dorsal pelage olive, ventral pelage pale yellow

results.verbatimLocality: Parc Bangr Weogo, Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso

results.occurrenceRemarks: Flew into house, captured and released outside.

I witnessed  a Black Mamba eating what I believe to be Yellow House Bats out of a hollow telephone pole More photos: https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.175170012638383.1073741833.139967912825260&type=3  Youtube video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JqQ5unQy5VQ&list=FLsFTukNHLeTUJfbt7ms2ZvQ&feature=mh_lolz

Caught regularly as by-catch during evening mist netting as part of bird banding project. Some were bright yellow which suggested S. dinganii and others had buff underparts suggesting S. leucogaster and others like this were intermediate pale yellow or yellowish grey
perfect akinese, really convincing - the bat left happily after
2008-10-28 : 2 ind captured 2008-10-29 : 4 ind captured (3 biopsie send to Dr RG Trijillo, University of MO, Columbia, MO, USA)  Forearm length : 51,4 Male / 52,5 Male / 54 Male / 55,4 Female

results.informationWithheld: Coordinate uncertainty increased by 10000m at the request of the observer

results.occurrenceRemarks: found caught on a barb on wire along top of security fence; caught through skin on left wing (ulna/humerus). A graze from the wire on left cheek from eye to just behind point of mouth. Identified by Natural History Museum, Zimbabwe
